author: somechap.
content: Just to add: specifically in the case of Rocket Pool, it's true that if hypothetically a single operator could put up 33% of all staked ETH and the protocol could match it then that operator would control 2/3rds of all validators, but the relevant comparison to mining pools is with the Rocket Pool network *as a whole* -- not a single operator. Even if Rocket Pool comprised 66% of all validators there would be no single party able to direct those validators to finalize a particular fork because Rocket Pool is a significantly decentralized protocol.

author: sky.cactus
content: Eh, I don't think it is safe to assume rocket pool is decentralized.  As you mentioned, we can't know that 33% of validators (all running clients) aren't one operator.

author: somechap.
content: well, some of the individual operators are doxxed so technically we do know that it is at least partially decentralized. but yes we don't technically know that all the anonymous operators aren't the same individual. I still think that's a big difference from a pool where we know for sure that it is centralized

author: somechap.
content: and to be clear I think it would be alarming if any pool or protocol would ever be anywhere close to 66% of staked ETH

author: somechap.
content: and one more thing before I shut up (promise!), we also can't technically be sure without social clues that all anonymous solo validators are not the same individual. there's a certain equivalence with rp there

author: m.kalinin
content: Sort of, but in rocket pool an individual may spend `X` ETH to gain `2X` power vs being a solo staker. Should such an intention exist one could exploit rocket pool to increase its validating power.
